document.docAuthor: Domahovski, Alexandre Cruz & Cavichioli, Rodney Ramiro
document.docTitle: Polana (Varpulana) sapitanduva Domahovski & Cavichioli, 2017, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Six new Brazilian species of Polana (Varpulana) (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Gyponini) with key to males

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Six new Brazilian species of Polana (Varpulana) (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Gyponini) with key to males

subSubSection.paragraph: Description (Male). Length 7.1 mm , (n=3), female, ( paratype ) 8.1 mm , (n= 5). Head ( Fig. 60 ) in dorsal view with median length approximately half as long as interocular width. Other characteristics as in generic description.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 76–87.
P. (F.) vulgaris
sp. nov.
, holotype male. 76, head and thorax, dorsal view. 77, head, frontal view. 78, head and thorax, lateral view. 79, forewing. 80–87, male terminalia: 80, sternite VIII, ventral view. 81, pygofer, valve and subgenital plate, lateral view. 82, apex of pygofer, ventral view. 83, subgenital plate, ventral view. 84, style and connective, dorsal view. 85, style, lateral view. 86, aedeagus, lateral view. 87, aedeagus posterior view. Scale bars: 76–78 = 1.0 mm, 79 = 2.0 mm, 80–8 1 = 0.5 mm, 82–87 = 0.25 mm.

FIGURES 88–91.
P.
(F.) vulgaris
sp. nov.
, female paratype terminalia: 88, sternite VII and pygofer, ventral view. 89, pygofer and valves, lateral view. 90, first valvifer and first valvulae, lateral view. 91, second valvulae, lateral view. Scale bars: 8 8 = 1.0 mm, 89–91 = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The new species name refers to the Reserva Biológica de Sapitanduva where the holotype was collected.

Remarks.
Polana (V.) sapitanduva
sp. nov.
is most similar to
P. (V.) naja
sp. nov.
in the style, which has the ventral protrusion of the blade elongated and arising more basally compared with the other species of Varpulana ; the shape of the aedeagal shaft elongated and curved and the shape of female sternite VII. However, the new species can be easily separated from other Varpulana species by the long and curved atrial processes.
